urls.resource_name: Unacast Social Distancing Scoreboard / COVID-19 Toolkit
urls.why_needed: Provides the original county-level distance-traveled change variable used to measure social-distancing behavior.

urls.resource_name: U.S. Census Bureau – American Community Survey 2014-18 5-year estimates
urls.why_needed: Source of county per-capita income and all sociodemographic covariates (race, education, industry, age, etc.) required by the design.

urls.resource_name: MIT Election Data & Science Lab – County Presidential Election Returns 2000-2020
urls.why_needed: Contains the 2016 county vote share for Donald Trump, the key political-orientation predictor.

urls.resource_name: 2010 Census Percent Urban/Rural by County file
urls.why_needed: Supplies the county rurality variable used as a control in the paper’s regressions.

urls.resource_name: Google COVID-19 Community Mobility Reports (global CSV, includes U.S. counties)
urls.why_needed: Open, regularly updated mobility data that can substitute for Unacast to draw a NEW replication sample covering later periods.
Publicly archived alternative cellphone-based mobility dataset allowing an independent replication if Unacast access is restricted.

missing.resource_name: Analysis & replication code (data cleaning, regression scripts)
missing.search_query: Kavanagh Goel Venkataramani social distancing GitHub OR OSF code

missing.resource_name: Direct download link for county-level Unacast daily mobility CSV (March 19-28 2020)
missing.search_query: Unacast COVID-19 county mobility dataset csv download

urls.why_needed: Original study analysed this file; it contains mathematics self-concept, memorisation strategy, individual ability plausible values and school identifiers used to verify the published coefficients.
Most recent PISA wave that still includes the SAL learning-strategy scales (incl. Memorisation) and mathematics self-concept items, allowing an up-to-date independent replication with a new sample.
Open-source R tools for importing PISA data, handling replicate weights and plausible values, and running multilevel or regression analyses needed for replication.
Provides high-level functions (e.g., pisa.reg.pv) that compute regression models with plausible values and BRR weights, matching the analytic approach of the original paper.
Stata routines developed by OECD for PISA that automate regression with plausible values and replicate weights; offers an alternative implementation for researchers working in Stata.

urls.resource_name: OECD ‘How to prepare and analyse the PISA database’ guide
urls.why_needed: Official documentation (with sample scripts) explaining variable names, replicate-weight design and the BRR method—all required to construct the moderator × school-ability interaction terms correctly.

missing.resource_name: Confirmation that the PISA 2012 student questionnaire contains both the mathematics self-concept scale (ST42-series) and the Memorisation strategy scale (ST27Q03–ST27Q06).
missing.search_query: PISA 2012 codebook mathematics self-concept memorisation variable names

urls.resource_name: OWID COVID-19 global dataset (cases, deaths, population, etc.)
urls.why_needed: Provides up-to-date country-level cumulative and per-million infection counts required to build the dependent variable for a NEW replication sample.

urls.resource_name: ECDC daily COVID-19 case counts (alternative source)
urls.why_needed: Optional cross-check or robustness source for confirmed infections if OWID is not preferred.

urls.resource_name: Gapminder combined EIU Democracy Index (all years) Google Sheet
urls.why_needed: Offers the Economist Intelligence Unit democracy scores for every country (annual series) that can be merged with the COVID data.
Direct, bulk offline copy of the same democracy-index dataset for programmatic use.
Quick look-up of the most recent EIU democracy scores if the Gapminder sheet has not yet been updated.

urls.resource_name: Average yearly temperature by country (World Bank CRU 1991-2020 climatology)
urls.why_needed: Supplies the environmental ‘mean annual temperature’ covariate used in the regression.

urls.resource_name: World Bank WDI – Trade (% of GDP)
urls.why_needed: Provides the ‘economic openness’ variable (imports + exports as % of GDP) for each country/year.
Needed to compute infections per million if using a case-count series that is not already population-standardised.

urls.resource_name: World Bank WDI – Population density (people per km²)
urls.why_needed: Optional control variable included in the original paper’s first specification.

urls.resource_name: World Bank WDI – Average annual precipitation (mm)
urls.why_needed: Optional environmental control (precipitation) tested in the original analysis.
Contains Python ETL scripts and documentation for reproducing / refreshing the OWID COVID dataset programmatically.

missing.resource_name: Author-supplied regression code (Excel/STATA/EVIEWS syntax) implementing the cross-sectional OLS models
missing.search_query: Hossain "Is the spread of COVID-19 across countries" replication code OR github OR "supplementary"

missing.resource_name: A ready-made country-level average-temperature CSV that is easier to automate than the Wikipedia table
missing.search_query: global mean annual temperature by country CSV site:data.gov or site:worldbank.org climate

urls.why_needed: Open, representative German samples (2020-2022) include items on ‘worry about COVID-19’ and gender, allowing an independent replication of the women-vs-men worry gap.
Gives the exact wording/scale anchors for the worry items so the replication can match the original operationalisation on the new dataset.
Contains R code to read, clean and analyse COSMO waves—useful template for computing gender differences and significance tests in the replication.
A second, independent nationally representative COVID-19 study with risk-perception items; can be used to test robustness of the claim on another fresh sample.

missing.resource_name: Gerhold et al. original March 19-23 2020 dataset (N=1,242)
missing.search_query: Gerhold COVID-19 risk perception coping raw data Germany March 2020

missing.resource_name: Original survey questionnaire used by Gerhold et al.
missing.search_query: “COVID-19: Risk perception and Coping strategies” questionnaire pdf

urls.why_needed: Main gateway to download the original Wave 4 file used by the paper and the newer Wave 5 file required for drawing a fresh replication sample with identical variables.

urls.resource_name: IFLS4 study page in World Bank Microdata Library
urls.why_needed: Secondary, stable landing page for the 2007-08 IFLS4 public files (including blood-pressure measurements) in case the RAND portal is temporarily unavailable.

urls.resource_name: IFLS4 Household Questionnaire (contains risk & time-preference module)
urls.why_needed: Documentation needed to replicate the construction of risk and time-preference variables exactly as in the original analysis.
Gives variable lists, file structure, and health-measurement protocols (e.g., BP averaging) that must be followed to recreate the ‘under-diagnosed hypertension’ outcome.
Shows the exact replication wave’s questionnaires, variable names, and measurement procedures—all required to generate the same constructs with new data.
Confirms that Wave 5 still contains the blood-pressure module and the lottery-based risk/time-preference module needed for the replication sample.

missing.resource_name: Author-supplied replication code (Stata/R scripts) for cleaning IFLS data, constructing the ‘under-diagnosed’ variable, and estimating the probit marginal effects
missing.search_query: "Education, individual time preferences, and asymptomatic disease detection" Stata do file OR replication code

urls.why_needed: Contains the 2006 science-module micro-data used in the original latent-class analysis; required to reconstruct the ‘traditional/modern/post-secular’ classes on the original time-period.
Provides the 2008 science-module data that were pooled with 2006 and 2010 in the published study.
Final wave in the authors’ pooled sample; needed to replicate original class formation and baseline effect sizes.
Includes the 2016 science module so a NEW independent sample can be drawn to replicate the claim on a later cohort.
Latest cumulative file with 2018–2024 waves; enables construction of the same variables on the most recent data for a fresh replication test.
Convenient interface for downloading custom extracts and codebooks for all variables (e.g., EVOLVED, BIGBANG, bible literalism) needed in the replication.
Provides template syntax for Lo–Mendell–Rubin and BIC tests that match the paper’s LCA procedure; useful starter code for re-implementing the analysis on new data.

missing.resource_name: Original Mplus and Stata scripts used by O’Brien & Noy (2015)
missing.search_query: "Traditional, Modern, and Post-Secular" Mplus code OR "post-secular" stata do file

missing.resource_name: Online supplemental tables detailing variable recodes (ASR Web appendix)
missing.search_query: "0003122414558919" supplemental material evolution big bang variable list

urls.resource_name: EPA State CO2 Emissions (fossil-fuel combustion) tables, 1990-2018/22
urls.why_needed: Dependent variable – annual state-level CO2 emissions used in the original study and for any new years.
Provides updated state CO2 totals through 2022 and sector detail if the older table is discontinued.

urls.resource_name: BLS State & Area Employment (SAE) – Table 4 average weekly hours
urls.why_needed: Key independent variable – average weekly hours worked per employee, by state and year.
Labor productivity (GDP per hour) needed for the ‘scale-effect’ control.

urls.resource_name: BEA GDP by State (annual, chained dollars & industry detail)
urls.why_needed: State GDP per capita (composition model) and manufacturing share of GDP covariates.
Total state energy production control variable, consistent with the original specification.
Annual state population totals for level and logged-population control.

urls.resource_name: American Community Survey 1-year Summary Files & API
urls.why_needed: Household size and working-age-population share variables; newer waves supply a fresh replication sample.

urls.resource_name: League of Conservation Voters (LCV) Scorecard archive
urls.why_needed: Raw vote scores used to build the state-level environmentalism index (1990-2005 baseline).

urls.resource_name: BLS State & Metro Area (SAE) flat files
urls.why_needed: Bulk, machine-readable version of state average weekly hours series for automated replication scripts.

missing.resource_name: Original authors’ Stata/R replication scripts for panel regressions
missing.search_query: "US Working Hours and Carbon Dioxide Emissions" replication code OR Stata do file OR GitHub OR Dataverse"

urls.why_needed: Contains the original RCT micro-data (household surveys, drug-shop records, symptom database) required to reproduce variable definitions and treatment assignments before attempting an independent replication.

urls.resource_name: Replication code archive for “Price Subsidies, Diagnostic Tests, and Targeting of Malaria Treatment”
urls.why_needed: Holds the Stata / R scripts used in the published paper; these provide the precise cleaning, construction, and estimation steps to be re-applied to a new sample.

Offers a fresh, nationally-representative household sample with malaria-test results and ACT treatment variables, permitting an independent replication of subsidy–access / targeting relationships in a later time period.

urls.why_needed: Provides party‐manifesto category counts that are used to locate parties on the economic and social policy dimensions and to calculate dispersion.
Contains ready-made R functions and API access for downloading CMP data and processing manifesto category codes.
Gives election-level seat shares needed to (1) count parties that win ≥1 % of seats and (2) compute the Effective Number of Parliamentary Parties (ENPP).
Alternative constituency-level results source if more recent or granular seat totals are required for a new replication sample.
Supplies district-magnitude and other electoral-rule variables used as controls (or robustness checks) in the original models.
Implements the Laakso-Taagepera formula to compute the Effective Number of Parties from the seat-share vectors extracted from ParlGov/CLEA.

missing.resource_name: Original authors’ replication scripts (PCA construction of economic & social dimensions, dispersion calculation, regressions)
missing.search_query: "Spatial Structure of Party Competition" replication files OR code OR .do OR .R

missing.resource_name: Machine-readable list of median district magnitudes (Cox 1997 Table 3.3) used as an alternative electoral-system control
missing.search_query: "Making Votes Count" median district magnitude dataset download

urls.why_needed: Provides manufacturing employment counts and sectoral value-added needed to build the dependent variable and productivity-gap covariate.

urls.resource_name: OECD International Trade by Commodity Statistics (ITCS)
urls.why_needed: Contains annual import and export values by partner region and SITC code, used to construct 'Imports from the South' (% GDP) and the other trade variables.

urls.resource_name: OECD International Direct Investment Statistics by Industry
urls.why_needed: Supplies outward and inward FDI flows/positions in manufacturing (% GDP) for the control variable in the regression system.

urls.resource_name: UN National Accounts Main Aggregates Database
urls.why_needed: Gives constant-price value-added series by industry that, combined with STAN employment, are needed to compute real labour-productivity growth differentials.

urls.resource_name: OECD Annual National Accounts, Volume I (Main Aggregates)
urls.why_needed: Provides GDP and population in PPP 2000 US$ used to calculate the 'National Affluence' variable (GDP per capita).
Contains unemployment rates used as a control variable and can validate manufacturing-employment denominators.

missing.resource_name: Replication-ready Stata or R code for the three-equation fixed-effects GLS/3SLS system
missing.search_query: Christopher Kollmeyer "Explaining Deindustrialization" replication code Stata OR github

urls.resource_name: ECDC global daily COVID-19 cases & deaths
urls.why_needed: Primary source used by the original study for calculating early‐pandemic infection‐growth slopes; can still be downloaded for the same March-2020 window to verify results or to reconstruct a comparable time-window with a fresh cutoff.

urls.resource_name: Our World in Data complete COVID-19 dataset
urls.why_needed: Best open, up-to-date alternative for drawing a NEW cross-national sample of case and death counts (post-2020) to carry out a strict replication of the tightness × efficiency hypothesis.

urls.resource_name: World Bank – Worldwide Governance Indicators (Government Effectiveness)
urls.why_needed: Provides the Government Effectiveness (a.k.a. Government Efficiency) index required for the interaction term.

urls.resource_name: IMF World Economic Outlook (Oct 2019) GDP per capita
urls.why_needed: Replicates the study’s GDP-per-capita control; also allows an updated control if a newer WEO vintage is chosen.
Supplies the national income-inequality covariate included in all models.

urls.resource_name: CIA World Factbook – Median Age by country
urls.why_needed: Re-creates the demographic control (median age).
Contains R/Stata scripts and the prepared country-level panel that document operationalisation steps needed to mirror the analysis on a new dataset.

urls.why_needed: Primary source of country-year entrepreneurship rates that constitute the outcome variable in the claim.
Single-year-of-age population counts used to compute or validate each country’s median age and age-rank measures.

urls.resource_name: UN World Population Prospects – Standard CSV files
urls.why_needed: Up-to-date cross-country median-age series for drawing a NEW replication sample beyond the original 2010 wave.
Provides the tertiary-education control (% adults with college) used in the authors’ baseline regressions.

urls.resource_name: Penn World Table (earlier releases – includes PWT 7.1)
urls.why_needed: Source of GDP per-capita levels and 5-year growth rates that enter the country-level control vector.

urls.resource_name: World Bank WDI – Fertility rate, total (SP.DYN.TFRT.IN)
urls.why_needed: Re-creates the fertility-rate control series employed in robustness checks.

urls.resource_name: World Bank Doing Business – Cost of business start-up (% GNI per capita)
urls.why_needed: Matches the ‘start-up cost’ institutional control used in the paper.
Independent survey that the authors use for external validation; allows replication on an alternative dataset.

urls.resource_name: International Property Rights Index (IPRI) 2010 report archive
urls.why_needed: Supplies the Property-Rights score control that is held constant in cross-section regressions.

urls.why_needed: Provides the micro-survey responses—including the ‘private ownership of business’ item—needed to compute a NEW polarization measure for the most recent wave.
Original study drew many country‒wave observations from Wave 4; access is required to reproduce authors’ calculations on the SAME sample.

urls.resource_name: World Development Indicators – General government final consumption expenditure (% of GDP)
urls.why_needed: Up-to-date, public measure of government consumption that matches the concept of ‘size of government’ and can be averaged over recent years for replication.

urls.resource_name: Economic Freedom of the World 2025 dataset (xlsx download link on page)
urls.why_needed: Contains the Gwartney & Lawson GOVCONS and GOVTRANSSUB variables exactly as used by the original authors.
Provides DEMOC scores to identify ‘strong democracies’ (Polity ≥ 9) for both the original and any updated cross-section.
Supplies party-system fragmentation measures (HERFGOV, NGOV, etc.) that condition some of the paper’s robustness checks.
One-stop source for many control variables used in the ‘long’ specification (GDP per capita, trade openness, fractionalization, corruption, trust, etc.).

urls.resource_name: IFN Working Paper 749 PDF (pre-publication version of the article)
urls.why_needed: Contains Appendix tables and variable definitions referenced by the journal article; helpful for variable reconstruction if journal supplementary file is unavailable.

missing.resource_name: Author replication code (Stata/R do-files) that generate polarization metrics and regression tables

urls.resource_name: Citymapper Mobility Index (CMI) raw CSV archive
urls.why_needed: Provides daily city-level mobility index used as the dependent variable; can be downloaded for new time-periods to create a fresh replication sample.
Open-source code that programmatically pulls CMI data (get_mob_idx) and thus automates data acquisition for replication.

Contains dated indicators for closure of non-essential businesses and other NPIs; can be merged with mobility data to code the ‘social-distancing measure’ treatment variable across countries and sub-national units.

urls.resource_name: COVID AMP (Analysis & Mapping of Policies) local-policy dataset
urls.why_needed: Offers city- and local-area level policy records worldwide, useful to replicate the study at the same municipal scale rather than national averages.
Alternative open source with classified ‘social-distancing’ and ‘lockdown’ variables that can validate or supplement policy-timing data.
Provides an updated, independent mobility series (driving/walking/transit) that can be used as a new outcome variable after CMI ended, satisfying replication with new data.
Another freely available mobility dataset (place-category specific) that can be used for robustness checks or for periods after Apple/CMI coverage.

Public substitute for the authors’ restricted SIGACT violence data; contains geo-coded insurgent events for the 2009 election period
Independent, up-to-date conflict-event series to replicate the violence measure on later elections or extended time windows
Alternative open terrorism/violence dataset if SIGACT or ACLED coverage is insufficient for certain years
Provides district-representative electrification and consumption controls used in the regression models
Population denominator required to scale violence incidents per 1,000 inhabitants
Elevation control and for calculating great-circle distance variables
Ready-made functions to run the last-digit χ² test and create fraud indicators on new election data

urls.why_needed: Contains anonymized micro-level responses (including job-satisfaction items and turnover-intention question) for the most recent survey waves; can be used to draw a NEW replication sample that matches the paper’s measures.
Provides questionnaire wording, variable names, weights and methodology needed to operationalize constructs (job satisfaction, turnover intention, demographics) with the Public Data File.

urls.why_needed: Provides all micro-data rounds (including new Round 11) required to construct individual‐level variables on political trust, immigration concern and controls.
Supplies the country-level governance quality index used as a macro control.
Source for per-capita social-protection spending needed for the Level-2 welfare-state control.
Contains national election vote-share data that can be filtered to create the far-right party popularity variable for each ESS country-year.
Macro-economic control (GDP per capita) at the survey-year level.
Provides national unemployment rates used as an additional macro control.
Alternative policy-context variable tested in robustness checks (immigrant integration policy generosity).
Allows construction of party salience to immigration, an optional moderator examined in the original paper’s appendix.
Open-source code base to estimate three-level models analogous to the proprietary HLM software used in the article.

urls.resource_name: Uttar Pradesh & Bihar Survey of Living Conditions (LSMS 1997-98)
urls.why_needed: Original household- and village-level survey used in the paper; necessary to reconstruct variables and replicate baseline estimates.
Contains the author’s Stata do-files and cleaned data extracts that show exactly how the published tables (including the 566.5 coefficient) were produced.

urls.resource_name: Census of India 2001 – Village Directory (amenities) files
urls.why_needed: Provides irrigation infrastructure, land-use and other village amenities that were merged to the LSMS villages as controls.

urls.resource_name: Central Ground Water Board – Ground-water Level Data (1994-present)
urls.why_needed: Source for village/district groundwater variables that proxy water availability and are used as instruments or controls.
Best publicly-available nationwide household/village panel with caste, agricultural income, irrigation and land ownership—allows an independent replication on a fresh sample.

urls.resource_name: India Village-Level Geospatial Socio-Economic Data Set 1991 & 2001 (NASA SEDAC)
urls.why_needed: Provides machine-readable village boundaries and census socio-economic variables that facilitate matching LSMS or IHDS villages to census data for robustness checks.

urls.resource_name: ELEMENT Study (Reading, Mathematics & English competence, Grade 4–6, Berlin)
urls.why_needed: Original sample used in the paper; provides the identical variables and tests needed to re-run (reproduce) the published models.
Documentation needed to identify variable names, construct test scores (English WLE, German reading, CFT, SES indices) and match them to the analysis.

urls.resource_name: NEPS Starting Cohort 3 (Grade 5) Scientific Use File
urls.why_needed: Provides a NEW nationally-representative German cohort with English achievement tests, German reading tests, home-language information and rich background variables—suitable for an independent replication on a fresh sample.
Alternative large-scale dataset containing English proficiency, German reading, home-language and covariates; can be used as an additional robustness/replication sample if NEPS variables differ.
